title.narrative: Prevent and Mitigate the Impact of Transboundary Zoonotic Diseases of Pandemic Potential through the IT Modernization of FAO Web-based Platforms

description.narrative: This project has two main objectives: (1) enhance existing systems for data collection, analysis, visualization, risk assessment capabilities and reporting on emerging transboundary animal and plant pests and diseases, including zoonotic diseases at the human-animal- plant-environment interface; and (2) improve national and community-level biosecurity capacities and systems through the implementation of FAO's Progressive Management Pathway for Terrestrial Animal Biosecurity.

title.narrative: Next Generation Information Systems for Animal Disease Reporting and Surveillance

description.narrative: This project includes five activities: 1) Risk based surveillance program for zoonotic coronaviruses including SARS-CoV-2 at the human-domestic-wildlife interface; 2) one health surveillance, risk analysis, and response to SARS-CoV-2 at the human-animal-wildlife interface including support to West Africa EpiX through a subgrant; 3) a subgrant to Texas A&M to support strengthening of veterinary health systems to facilitate trade; 4) prevent and mitigate the impact of emerging animal diseases with pandemic building capacity in African, Middle East, and Eastern Europe/Central Asia through a subgrant agreement with the Center for Animal Health and Food Safety; and 5) support to the WOAH's digital transformation to improve data collection and data management to ensure members have access to data.

description.narrative: APHIS supported the International Training Program in Tropical Emerging and Re-emerging Diseases in Animals in Thailand. This effort supported capacity building of international veterinarians on surveillance and diagnosis of Tropical Emerging and Re-emerging Diseases in Animals. On November 12, 2012 APHIS Bangkok attended the opening ceremony of the training which was funded through the Dept. of State Biological Engagement Program. There were 15 participants from 14 countries including Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia, Philippines, Thailand, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Pakistan, Egypt, Mongolia, Ethiopia, Senegal, Samoa and Suriname. title.narrative: International Workshop on Alternative Methods for Human and Veterinary Rabies Vaccine Testing

description.narrative: On October 11-13, the CVB hosted the International Workshop on Alternative Methods for Human and Veterinary Rabies Vaccine Testing: State of the Science and Planning the Way Forward at the National Centers for Animal Health. This workshop, organized by the National Toxicology Program Interagency Center for Evaluation of Alternative Toxicology Methods and the Interagency Coordinating Committee on the Validation of Alternative Methods, will bring together international experts from regulatory agencies, academia, and industry to focus on reviewing current methods of rabies vaccine testing and to propose efforts necessary to implement an in vitro rabies potency test. Participants: US (55), Canada (2), France (4), UK (1), Germany (3), India (1), Japan (3), Mexico (1), Brazil (2), Switzerland (3), Netherlands (2), Italy (1), Argentina (1), Nigeria (1), Sudan (1).

title.narrative: International Workshop on Alternative Methods for Leptospira Vaccine Potency Testing

description.narrative: On September 19-21, the CVB hosted the International Workshop on Alternative Methods for Leptospira Vaccine Potency Testing: State of the Science and the Way forward, at the National Centers for Animal Health facilities in Ames, Iowa. The workshop was sponsored by the National Toxicology Program Interagency Center for the Evaluation of Alternative Toxicological Methods, and the Interagency Coordinating Committee on the Validation of Alternative Methods. The agenda focused on scientific review of currently available potency tests, national and international regulatory requirements for such tests, the current hamster vaccination-challenge model, and possible development of in vitro tests for Leptospira vaccines. Funding: Interagency Center for the Evaluation of Alternative Toxicological Methods (Health and Human Services, National Institutes of Health, National Toxicology Program). Participants: 80+

title.narrative: Training Course

description.narrative: Agricultural Biotechnology Short Course: This course was held at the Michigan State University, September 10 - 21, 2012. BRS provided an overview of APHIS regulatory policy on the first day of this two week course which was conducted in collaboration with USDA-FAS. The FAS-sponsored students, which made up about half of the class, are part of the Cochran Fellowship Program and mainly came from Latin America. The remaining students were from Sub-Sahara Africa and Southeast Asia. During the conclusion of this short course in Washington DC, BRS also represented APHIS on a panel of regulators. BRS expects to participate in this short course again in 2013.

title.narrative: Training Course

description.narrative: The Plant Health Systems Analysis Course is designed to illustrate how the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) confronts challenges posed by global and domestic plant health issues. The two-week course includes an overview of APHIS, interactions with other Federal and State agencies, international organizations, foreign governments, industry, and the general public in order to address plant health issues of mutual concern. Field trips to the National Plant Germplasm Inspection Station in Beltsville, Maryland, Port of Entry Plant Inspection facilities and Domestic Plant Health and research activities are also included. At the end of the course, participants assess how their organizations respond to plant health issues

title.narrative: World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) Focal Point Seminar

description.narrative: On October 1-5, APHIS represented USDA at the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) Focal Point Seminar and the Committee of the Americas for the Harmonization of Registration and Control of Veterinary Medicines (CAMEVET) meeting held in Sao Paulo, Brazil, representing the import/export interests of the U.S., as well as collaborating with regulatory counterparts from all the countries of the Americas (North, South, and Central). A representative from CVB also represented the USDA as the OIE Focal Point for veterinary medicinal products, and the USDA collaborating Centre for Vaccine Evaluation in the Americas, presenting information on the USDA biologics program activities during the OIE Focal Point sessions. Funding: CVB for CVB participants, conference funded by CAMEVET.

title.narrative: Wildlife Disease Monitoring and Management Course

description.narrative: From May 21-28, The USDA Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), International Technical and Regulatory Capacity Building (ITRCB) Center coordinated with Colorado State University and APHIS National Wildlife Research Center (NWRC) in Fort Collins, Colorado to complete the Wildlife Disease Monitoring and Management Course. The objectives of the Wildlife Disease Monitoring and Management course were to provide an international audience of wildlife management officials with the tools to effectively design and implement disease monitoring and management plans; how to implement best practices in diagnostic samples including biosafety protocols, field methods for collecting samples from wildlife species, biosafety and biosecurity protocols in sample handling and storage, compliance with international shipping requirements, diagnostic test selection, interpretation of diagnostic test results, and compliance with reporting standards.

description.narrative: Ms. Kenia Campo, UWI, Entomology Research and Phd candidate was funded to travel to the University of Arizona to complete her training in the molecular analysis and bio typing of the whitefly Bemisia tabaci (Gennadius) (Hemiptera: Aleyrodidae). Bemisia tabaci is a species complex with global distribution and extensive genetic diversity. It causes excessive crop losses through directly feeding and transmission of plant viruses. The main tropical and sub-tropical regions of the world, has been a major challenge to agricultural scientists in both developing and industrialized nations. In the late 1980s, tomato producing areas in Latin America and across the tropics began to suffer from high incidences of whitefly-borne begomoviruses with devastating economic consequences. The training at the University of Arizona, therefore involved DNA isolation from whiteflies, Polymerase chain reaction of mtCOI gene, cloning of PCR products, DNA sequencing, Sequence assembly, alignment, phylogenetic analysis and procurement of reading literature on whitefly taxonomy with B. tabaci emphasis.

title.narrative: Agriculture Inspection Quarantine (AQI) and Border Security Improvement Project

description.narrative: APHIS hosted a technical information exchange with the Mongolian General Agency for Specialized Inspection (GASI) and the Veterinary and Animal Breeding Agency (VABA) between May 13th and 19th. Mongolia, a landlocked democratic nation, has Soviet era port-of-entry state-owned facilities. The government of Mongolia received an international grant to modernize two land ports (for the northern and southern borders) that will complement the recently built modern international airport. Towards this end, a Mongolian delegation of five visited the Port of Champlain (land port), JFK (airport), and APHIS VS live animal import facility in New York State. This coordinated effort, led by Dr. Connie Bacon, included APHIS-IS, VS, DHS-CBP, and the U.S. Embassy in Mongolias Economic and Commercial Section. The weeklong event provided a rare behind the scenes overview of U.S. port-of-entry operations to include commercial and passenger cargo screening as well as the interception, seizure, and destruction of regulated articles. title.narrative: Wildlife Disease Monitoring and Management Course

description.narrative: The Wildlife Disease Monitoring and Management Course combined classroom sessions led by subject matter experts with operational experience, including laboratory-based and field exercises where participants can apply their classroom learning in a live setting under subject matter expert supervision. The course was designed to highlight the connection between Wildlife Disease Monitoring and Management concepts and the applied field techniques used to implement these concepts. The course highlighted highly contagious animal diseases and transboundary animal diseases such as African swine fever, highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) and foot-and-mouth disease (FMD), among others, which continue to impact communities around the world. Biosafety and biosecurity protocols were a key component of the course, including review of the National Wildlife Research Center facility to demonstrate containment and management criteria for facilities that work with zoonotic pathogens and use of personal protective equipment.

title.narrative: High-Containment Laboratory Practices and Techniques Seminar

description.narrative: The High Containment Laboratory Practices and Techniques seminar at Kansas State University will equip participants from multiple countries with the fundamental background to safely participate in high containment laboratory activities and develop practices and techniques promoting biosafety, biosecurity, and biocontainment in a research laboratory or academic setting. It aims to develop hands-on techniques as well as foster participant analytical skills using problem based learning, reviewing agents and toxins, research, guidelines, and rationales that dictate high containment laboratory practices. Participants will develop an understanding of standard microbiological practices and will be introduced to principles and techniques required to work safely and securely with biohazards materials in BSL-3 laboratories. They will explore biological risk groups and agent characteristics to conduct initial and ongoing risk assessments. Based on the risk assessment they will determine which biological safety level, practice, and technique is best suited for the planned laboratory and research activities. Participants will practice hands-on skills and techniques in a training laboratory to acquire and reinforce their own positive work practices while learning to identify and encourage safe and secure practices in others. Activities will consist of lecture, classroom discussion, individual and group activities, and hands-on skills development.

title.narrative: Field Study - Copenhagen: the Mothers Infants and Lactation Quality (MILQ) Project

description.narrative: Breast milk is recommended as the sole source of nutrients for infants during the first 180 days postpartum and as an important source for the next 200 days, but we lack valid information on the nutrient content of human milk, and especially on its micronutrient (MN) content, and there are no Reference Values (RVs). Consequently we are basing recommended nutrient intakes of infants, young children and lactating women on many unvalidated and incorrect estimates of milk MN concentrations and have no benchmarks against which to evaluate breast milk quality in different populations, or the need for or effects of nutrient interventions on breast milk micronutrients. The limited existing evidence suggests that many vitamins and some minerals may be low in the milk of undernourished women. The overall objective of this research is to develop RVs for micronutrients in human milk, based on the range of nutrient concentrations in samples that we will obtain from well-nourished but unsupplemented lactating women in four countries. Maternal plasma will also be collected to verify the adequacy of maternal micronutrient status and to describe the relationships between maternal status and milk micronutrient concentrations. Infant plasma will be analyzed to determine the effects of breast milk micronutrient concentrations on infant status. These objectives will be facilitated by our recent validation of methods for milk micronutrient analysis, and our ability to measure several vitamins simultaneously by mass spectrometry.

title.narrative: Emergency Poultry Disease Response and Regionalization Symposium and Veterinary Diagnostic Quality Laboratory Assurance (VDLQA) Course

description.narrative: The Emergency Poultry Disease Response and Regionalization (EPDRR) Symposium is designed to assist participants in understanding the elements of successfully planning for and responding to a poultry disease outbreak, including state/regional and national policies, dealing with live bird markets/backyard flocks, and incident command structure. The VDLQA course is designed to provide veterinary laboratory and quality assurance professionals with skills that include direct involvement with laboratory quality assurance procedures, laboratory diagnostics, and biosecurity. The course will allso incude modules related to laboratory management structure, and surveillance of wild birds and commercial poultry.

title.narrative: Cooperative Agreement with University of Delaware

description.narrative: USDA APHIS provided funding to the University of Delaware's Emergency Poultry Disease Response Course. The course focused on three critical aspects of successfully managing poultry disease outbreaks, emphasizes rapid response techniques of depopulation, disposal and decontamination. Experts from the University of Delaware, Poultry Producers and State/Federal Governments addressed cooperation issues and strategic planning to address emergency poultry disease outbreak situations. 16 participants from 16 countries attended, with a focus on African countries.

title.narrative: Defense Threat Reduction Agency

description.narrative: Supports the National Strategy for Countering Biological Threats by meeting the following objectives: 1) Expand international partnerships and bioengagement; 2) Strengthen partners capacities to comply with World Organization for Animal Health guidelines for surveillance, detection, diagnosis and reporting of notifiable diseases; 3) Promote development of international guidelines for safety and security of high risk pathogens/toxins; 4) Support partner efforts to apply safety and security practices in a risk-based and sustainable manner; 5) Promote development of international guidelines for safety and security of high risk pathogens/toxins; 6) Building knowledge as to the disease burden and technological capabilities in partner countries; and, 7) Building international capacity against infectious diseases in partner countries

title.narrative: Biological Engagement Program (BEP); Defense Threat Reduction (DOD)

description.narrative: Veterinary Epidemiology Course, CEAH - This course, in collaboration with Colorado State University, is designed to provide veterinarians with basic skills and concepts in epidemiology with an emphasis on the role of this discipline in national animal health programs. An emphasis on highly contagious animal diseases and important transboundary diseases such as highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) and Foot and Mouth Disease which continue to be significant threats to animal health in regions around the world. The FY 2012 course had 24 participants from various developing countries

title.narrative: Biosecurity Engagement Program (BEP) and Defense Threat Reduction (DTRA)

description.narrative: Risk Analysis for Animal Health Course, USDA/CEAH - Participants learned skills to conduct a qualitative risk assessment and were introduced to the fundamentals of risk analysis, and its use in decision-making from the perspectives of both risk managers and technical risk analysts. Participants were introduced to OIE guidelines for qualitative risk analysis and how risk analysis techniques are used to help design programs for control of domestic animal diseases and to handle trade issues. A brief introduction to quantitative risk assessment was provided.

description.narrative: Diagnostic Laboratory Network Course - APHIS International Services in conjunction with Veterinary Services Professional Development Staff and the National Veterinary Services Laboratory, developed an International Diagnostic Laboratory Network Training as a means to standardize laboratory testing methods, streamline communications between regional and central/reference laboratories in order to efficiently process diagnostic requests and share information. The 2nd annual course in FY 2012 had 16 participants from South Asia, the Middle East, East Africa, and the Former Soviet Union.

title.narrative: Biosecurity Engagement Program (BEP); Defense Threat Reduction (DOD)

description.narrative: International Transboundary Animal Disease course combines classroom and laboratory exercises enabling participants to first review the etiology of the specific transboundary animal disease being studied. During the two weeks of the course, participants conduct clinical examinations of animals inoculated with selected transboundary animal diseases (TADs) and later perform full necropsies under the direction of USDA foreign animal disease experts. This experience of observing the clinical symptoms and then conducting hands-on necropsies provides the most comprehensive and practical way to study these diseases. APHIS hosted 28 veterinary officials at the PIADC, an agricultural biosecurity level 3 facility , which involves strict security protocols for entry and exit from Plum Island and the biosecure laboratories located at Orient Point, NY.

title.narrative: FSIS Food Defense

description.narrative: In an effort to address the topic of food defense in the FSIS executed a series of food defense awareness workshops. The workshops raised awareness of the importance of protecting the food supply chain against intentional contamination and provided voluntary low cost/no-cost approaches to protect the safety and integrity of international food and agricultural trade.

title.narrative: New Task Order Development

description.narrative: The purpose of this task order is to avoid Ant deficiency Act violations by having a reserve of money available for USDA to charge staff time and other MCC-related expenses that accrue in the time before a specific task order is signed to allocate funding for that purpose. In general, USDA staff charge time to this account while working on task order development for MCC. This includes budget drafting, editing and disseminating a scope of work, and meeting with MCC staff as appropriate. This task order also covers USDA time spent on more general MCC program tasks that relate to the whole interagency agreement rather than to any specific task order.

title.narrative: Visiting Scientists Program

description.narrative: Foreign researchers engage in collaborative reserarch programs at the Agricultural Research Service and other USDA agencies. Foreign researchers come for both short-term and long-term visits, as well as technical workshops, meetings and conferences. In FY 2012, 25 researchers shared their expertise in U.S. laboratories.

title.narrative: Cochran Fellowship Program

description.narrative: Training midlevel agriculturalists on various agriculture-related topics, such as sustainable agriculture, plant and animal health, food safety,agricultural policy and trade, agribusiness management, and marketing. The objectives of this short-term training are to help countries meet their domestic food needs as well as to enhance trade links with U.S. agricultural interests. In FY12, approximately 479 individuals received such training, resulting in a better understanding of science-based agricultural regulatory systems, increased trade, and enhanced technical capacities in their home countries.

title.narrative: Faculty Exchange Program

description.narrative: The Faculty Exchange Program enhances the teaching ability of agricultural educators from institutions of higher learning in developing countries. Participants come to the United States for one academic semester (4-5 months) to increase their knowledge of, and ability to teach, agricultural economics, marketing, business and law in a market-based economy.
